issues.description: The solution implementation declares the Lecture attributes using snake_case names (e.g. lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, etc.) but the constructor, getters, setters and other methods use camelCase field names (e.g. lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, etc.). This name mismatch means the solution code will not compile (unresolved symbol errors) and is inconsistent with the UML / problem statement which uses camelCase names. Students reading the solution will be confused about the correct attribute names and may be blocked when trying to follow or test the reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make attribute names consistent across the solution implementation and match the UML/problem statement. For example, change the declared fields to camelCase: private String lectureName; private int numberOfInscribedStudents; private int numberOfGuestStudents; private int numberOfLecturers; private int numberOfTutors; — or alternatively change all usages (constructor, getters, setters, methods) to use the declared snake_case names. Prefer aligning the field names with the UML (camelCase) so the solution matches the specification and is clear to students.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) expects the Lecture attributes to use camelCase identifiers: lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers and numberOfTutors. In the solution implementation the fields are declared with snake_case names (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors) while the rest of the solution (constructor, getters, setters and methods) uses camelCase identifiers (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, etc.). This creates a clear naming mismatch: the declared field names do not match the identifiers referenced elsewhere in the same class and do not match the names used in the problem UML. This will confuse students mapping the UML to the implementation and also introduces compilation/runtime errors in the solution code because references (e.g., this.lectureName) refer to non-existent fields.
issues.suggested_fix: Use consistent camelCase attribute names that match the problem statement UML and the rest of the solution. Rename the declared fields in solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java as follows: lecture_name -> lectureName, number_of_inscribed_students -> numberOfInscribedStudents, number_of_guest_students -> numberOfGuestStudents, number_of_lecturers -> numberOfLecturers, number_of_tutors -> numberOfTutors. Alternatively, change all references (constructor, getters, setters, methods) to use the snake_case names, but aligning to the UML/camelCase is recommended to follow Java conventions and avoid student confusion. Ensure the template and solution use the same identifiers so students can clearly map the UML to the implementation.
